questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'We ran all the way. We were late for school.'
questions.answer: We ran all the way, yet we were late for school.
questions.explanation: The two statements show contrast/opposition. 'Yet' or 'but' is appropriate for showing this contrast.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'Shut the door. The dog will go out.'
questions.answer: Shut the door or the dog will go out.
questions.explanation: This shows a choice/alternative. 'Or' is the appropriate conjunction showing this alternative.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'He is honest. His father is also honest.'
questions.answer: He is honest as well as his father.
questions.explanation: This shows addition of similar facts. 'As well as' joins two similar statements.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'He gave the beggar money. He gave the beggar clothes.'
questions.answer: He gave the beggar not only money but also clothes.
questions.explanation: This shows addition of two things. 'Not only...but also' is the appropriate correlative conjunction.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'The weather was fine. The sea was calm.'
questions.answer: The weather was fine and the sea was calm.
questions.explanation: 'And' is the simple coordinating conjunction to join these two statements of equal rank.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'He worked hard. He did not succeed.'
questions.answer: He worked hard, but he did not succeed.
questions.explanation: This shows contrast/opposition. 'But' or 'yet' are appropriate to show this opposition.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'They are poor. They are happy.'
questions.answer: They are poor, but they are happy.
questions.explanation: This shows contrast. 'But' shows contrast between poverty and happiness.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'Fred worked all day. He didn't finish his work.'
questions.answer: Fred worked all day, yet he didn't finish his work.
questions.explanation: This shows contrast/opposition. 'Yet' shows that despite working all day, the work wasn't finished.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'We loved her. We appreciated her.'
questions.answer: We both loved and appreciated her.
questions.explanation: 'Both...and' joins these statements showing both actions were done.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'Wise men work hard. Fools waste their time.'
questions.answer: Wise men work hard, whereas fools waste their time.
questions.explanation: 'Whereas' shows contrast/comparison between two types of people.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'We are grateful to you. We are equally grateful to your brother.'
questions.answer: We are not only grateful to you but also to your brother.
questions.explanation: 'Not only...but also' expresses gratitude to both people.

questions.question: Join using Co-ordinating Conjunctions: 'I relished the dinner. My friend also relished the dinner.'
questions.answer: Both I and my friend relished the dinner.
questions.explanation: 'Both...and' shows both people enjoyed the dinner.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'Be attentive. Leave the class.'
questions.answer: Either be attentive or leave the class.
questions.explanation: 'Either...or' presents a choice between two alternatives.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'She is not lazy. She is not careless.'
questions.answer: She is neither lazy nor careless.
questions.explanation: 'Neither...nor' is used when negating both alternatives.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'India has rich resources. It is poor.'
questions.answer: Though India has rich resources, yet it is poor.
questions.explanation: 'Though...yet' shows contrast/concession.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'They do not pay the rent. They do not vacate the house.'
questions.answer: They neither pay the rent nor vacate the house.
questions.explanation: 'Neither...nor' shows negation of both actions.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'He stole my purse. He stole my books.'
questions.answer: He stole both my purse and my books.
questions.explanation: 'Both...and' shows both items were stolen.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'We reached the station. Soon the train left.'
questions.answer: No sooner had we reached the station than the train left.
questions.explanation: 'No sooner...than' shows two actions happening in quick succession.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'She is intelligent. She is hardworking.'
questions.answer: She is both intelligent and hardworking.
questions.explanation: 'Both...and' shows she possesses both qualities.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'The intensity of her grief was great. She could not weep even.'
questions.answer: Such was the intensity of her grief that she could not weep.
questions.explanation: 'Such...that' shows result or consequence.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'She sang very sweetly. The whole hall resounded with cheers.'
questions.answer: She sang so sweetly that the whole hall resounded with cheers.
questions.explanation: 'So...that' shows cause-effect relationship.

questions.question: Join using Correlative Conjunctions: 'She can speak French. She can speak German.'
questions.answer: She can speak both French and German.
questions.explanation: 'Both...and' shows she can speak both languages.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with suitable Subordinating Conjunction: 'He asked me _____ I could lend him money.'
questions.answer: if
questions.explanation: 'If' is used because this is an indirect question (yes/no question).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'She said _____ she was not very confident.'
questions.answer: that
questions.explanation: 'That' introduces a noun clause in indirect speech.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The boy _____ is coming is my brother.'
questions.answer: who
questions.explanation: 'Who' is a relative pronoun introducing an adjective clause describing a person.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I know the man _____ son has died in the accident.'
questions.answer: whose
questions.explanation: 'Whose' is a relative pronoun showing possession.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The book _____ I bought yesterday is interesting.'
questions.answer: which/that
questions.explanation: 'Which' or 'that' are relative pronouns introducing an adjective clause describing a thing.

questions.question: Combine using Subordinating Conjunctions: 'I did not know her. I met her.'
questions.answer: I did not know her until I met her.
questions.explanation: 'Until/till' shows time up to which something was true.

questions.question: Combine using Subordinating Conjunctions: 'Om is honest. Jai is more honest.'
questions.answer: Though Om is honest, Jai is more honest.
questions.explanation: 'Though' shows that while Om has the quality, Jai has it to a greater degree.

questions.question: Combine using Subordinating Conjunctions: 'She can buy her school books. You lend her some money.'
questions.answer: She can buy her school books if you lend her some money.
questions.explanation: 'If' introduces a condition.

questions.question: Combine using Subordinating Conjunctions: 'The rains came in time. There was a drought.'
questions.answer: The rains came in time before there was a drought.
questions.explanation: 'Before' shows time sequence - rains prevented drought.

questions.question: Combine using Subordinating Conjunctions: 'Shyam met many women. He decided to marry Priya.'
questions.answer: After Shyam met many women, he decided to marry Priya.
questions.explanation: 'After' shows time sequence.

questions.question: Combine using Subordinating Conjunctions: 'Mother has joined Yoga Classes. She is fit and healthy.'
questions.answer: Since mother has joined Yoga Classes, she is fit and healthy.
questions.explanation: 'Since' shows the result that came after joining.

questions.question: Combine using Subordinating Conjunctions: 'My mother cannot buy that expensive necklace. She does not have enough money.'
questions.answer: My mother cannot buy that expensive necklace because she does not have enough money.
questions.explanation: 'Because' shows the reason/cause.

questions.question: Combine using Subordinating Conjunctions: 'He found his handbag. He had forgotten it under the seat.'
questions.answer: He found his handbag which he had forgotten under the seat.
questions.explanation: 'Which' introduces a relative clause describing the handbag.

questions.question: Combine using Subordinating Conjunctions: 'She is seven years old. She does not go to school.'
questions.answer: Though she is seven years old, she does not go to school.
questions.explanation: 'Though' shows contrast - normally seven-year-olds go to school, but she doesn't.

questions.question: What are Conjunctions?
questions.answer: Conjunctions are words that grammatically join words, groups of words, phrases, clauses or sentences. Examples include 'and', 'but', 'or', 'because', 'when', 'if', etc.
questions.explanation: Conjunctions are connecting words that link different parts of sentences together.

questions.question: What are the three main types of Conjunctions?
questions.answer: The three main types are: 1) Coordinating Conjunctions (join words/sentences of equal rank), 2) Correlative Conjunctions (used in pairs), 3) Subordinating Conjunctions (join dependent clause to main clause).
questions.explanation: Each type serves a different grammatical purpose in joining sentence elements.

questions.question: What are Coordinating Conjunctions? Give examples.
questions.answer: Coordinating Conjunctions join two words or independent sentences of equal rank. Examples: and, but, or, yet, so, for. E.g., 'The sun set and the night fell.'
questions.explanation: Coordinating means 'of equal rank or importance'.

questions.question: What are Correlative Conjunctions? Give examples.
questions.answer: Correlative Conjunctions are used in pairs and convey their full sense only when used together. Examples: either...or, neither...nor, both...and, not only...but also, no sooner...than.
questions.explanation: These conjunctions work in pairs to create balanced sentence structures.
